metadata.case_name: Sharda Prasad & Ors. v. Jumna Prasad & Ors.

facts.text: Partition suit brought by Jumna Prasad, Devi Prasad and two minor sons of Jumna Prasad against Gajju Lal, his son Jawala Prasad, four minor sons of Jawala Prasad (Sharda Prasad, Dharam Pal, Ram Pal, Krishna Pal) and Smt. Sundari.
Decree made by Civil Judge, Kanpur on September 2, 1938, awarding house formerly bearing No. 36/22 and 36/58, Etawa Bazar, Kanpur, along with other properties to the defendants.

Execution application made by Sharda Prasad, Dharam Pal, Ram Pal and Krishna Pal on November 23, 1949, praying for delivery of possession over Etawa Bazar house, dispossessing Jumna Prasad and Devi Prasad, along with Gajju Lal, Jawala Prasad and Smt. Sundari.
Applicants stated they had been minors up till then and one still minor, so no question of limitation arises.
This was the first application for execution of the partition decree.
Principal objection: application barred by time, as Jawala Prasad could give discharge under s.7 Limitation Act without concurrence of minor sons.
Trial Court held Jawala Prasad could not give valid discharge, application within time.

Allahabad High Court, in Execution First Appeal No. 224 of 1951, judgment dated October 15, 1954, held Jawala Prasad as Karta could act for joint family, give discharge by taking possession, application barred by limitation.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) Constitution, leading to this appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.7 of Limitation Act applies to partition decree for possession.
Whether Jawala Prasad as Karta could give valid discharge of liability under decree without concurrence of minor sons, in view of O.32 CPC.
Whether execution application barred by limitation under s.7 Limitation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.7 Limitation Act does not apply to partition decree, as 'discharge' appropriate only for monetary claims.
Jawala Prasad could not give valid discharge due to O.32 CPC provisions.

respondent_arguments.text: Jawala Prasad as Karta of Hindu joint family could give discharge by taking possession on behalf of entire family, so time ran against minors from decree date under s.7 Limitation Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.7 Limitation Act; Hindu Law (Karta powers)

court_reasoning.text: 'Discharge' in s.7 Limitation Act not limited to monetary claims but applies to all liabilities including possession under partition decree; illustrations and s.8 confirm broad application.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discharge means to free from liability, applicable to decrees requiring action or forbearance.

court_reasoning.text: O.32 r.6,7 CPC do not apply: no money/movables received, no agreement/compromise; acceptance of possession not an agreement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Karta can take possession on behalf of family including minors in partition decree execution.

court_reasoning.text: Jawala Prasad could give discharge by accepting possession, time ran from decree date against minors under s.7; High Court correct.

holdings.text: S.7 Limitation Act applies to partition decrees for possession; 'discharge' not limited to monetary claims.
Karta of Hindu joint family can give discharge by accepting possession under partition decree without O.32 CPC bar.

precedents_cited.relevance: Guardian ad litem's acts subject to court control under O.32 r.7 equivalent; no authority for compromise binding minor.
Karta as guardian cannot give valid discharge for money/movables under O.32 r.6.
Karta as guardian cannot give valid discharge for money/movables under O.32 r.6.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: S.7: Discharge by one joint creditor bars others; applies to partition possession; S.8 exempts pre-emption.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Limits guardian's power for receipt of money/movables or compromise; does not apply to possession acceptance.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate granted for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Allahabad High Court that the execution application was barred by limitation under s.7 Limitation Act, as Jawala Prasad could give discharge by accepting possession.

key_quotes.text: 'Discharge means, to free from liability. The liability may be in respect of monetary claims... it may be in respect of possession of property...'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Broad interpretation of 'discharge' under s.7 Limitation Act.

key_quotes.text: Acceptance of delivery of possession of property in terms of the decree in a partition suit can by no stretch of imagination be considered entering into any agreement or compromise.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes from O.32 r.6,7 CPC restrictions.
